titleStmt.title: A Machine-Readable Version of The Taming of A Shrew, 1594

sourceDesc.p: From the LION version of STC23667, 1594, checked against page images from EEBO

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Slie. Lord. Phylotus Duke of Cestus Saunders Ferando Boy. Kate Emilia Phelina Valeria Polidor Aurelius Alfonso Messenger One Another Will Tom Haberdasher Tailor The other Tapster. Seruingman.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter a Tapster, beating out of his doores Slie Droonken

sp.l: You whoreson drunken slave, you had best be gone,
And empty your drunken paunch some where else
for in this house thou shalt not rest tonight .

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Tilly vally, by crisee Tapster I will feeze you anon.
Fills the the other pot and all is paid for, look you
I do drink it of mine own Instigation,
here I will lie a while, why Tapster I say,
Fills a fresh cushion here.
Heigh ho, here is good warm lying.
He falls asleep.

body.stage: Enter a Noble man and his men from hunting.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Now that the gloomy shadow of the night,
Longing to view Orions drizzling looks,
Leaps from the antarctic World unto the sky
And dims the Welkin with her pitchy breath,
And darksome night over-shades the crystal heavens,
Here break we off our hunting for tonight ,
Couple up the hounds and let us hie us home,
And bid the huntsman see them meated well,
for they have all deserved it well today ,
But soft, what sleepy fellow is this lies here?
Or is he dead, see one what he doth lack?

sp.speaker: Seruingman.
sp.l: My lord, it is nothing but a drunken sleep,
His head is too heavy for his body,
And he hath drunk so much that he can go no further.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Fie, how the slavish villain stinks of drink.
Ho, sirra arise. What so sound asleep?
Go take him up and bear him to my house,
And beat him easily for fear he wake,
And in my fairest chamber make a fire,
And set a sumptuous banquet on the board,
And put my richest garments on his back,
Then set him at the Table in a chair:
When that is done against he shall awake,
Let heavenly music play about him still,
Go two of you away and bear him hence,
And then I will tell you what I have devised,
But see in any case you wake him not.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Now take my cloak and give me one of yours,
all fellows now, and see you take me so,
for we will wait upon this drunken man,
to see his countenance when he doth awake
And find himself clothed in such attire,
With heavenly music sounding in his ears,
And such a banquet set before his eyes,
The fellow sure will think he is in heaven,
But we will be about him when he wakes,
And see you call him Lord, at every word,
And offer thou him his horse to ride abroad,
And thou his hawks and hounds to hunt the deer ,
And I will ask what suits he means to wear,
And what so ere he saith, see you do not laugh,
But still persuade him that he is a Lord.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: If it please your honour your players be come
And do attend your honours pleasure here.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The fittest time they could have chosen out,
Bid one or two of them come hither straight,
Now will I fit myself accordingly,
for they shall play to him when he awakes.

body.stage: Enter two of the players with packs at their backs, and a boy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Now sirs, what store of plays have you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Marry my lord you may have a Tragical
Or a commodity, or what you will.

sp.speaker: The other.
sp.l: A comedy thou shouldst say, 'swounds thou wilt shame us all.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And what is the name of your Comedy?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Marry my lord it is called The taming of a shrew:
it is a good lesson for us my lord, for us you are married men

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The taming of a shrew, that is excellent sure,
Go see that you make you ready straight,
for you must play before a lord tonight ,
Say you are his men and I your fellow,
he is something foolish, but what so ere he says,
See that you be not dashed out of countenance.
And sirra go you make you ready straight,
And dress yourself like some lovely lady,
And when I call see that you come to me,
for I will say to him thou art his wife,
Dally with him and hug him in thine arms,
And if he desire to go to bed with thee,
Then fain some scuse and say thou wilt anon.
Be gone I say, and see thou dost it well.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: fear not my Lord, I will dandle him well enough
And make him think I love him mightily.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Now sirs go you and make you ready too ,
for you must play as soon as be doth wake.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: O brave, sirra Tom, we must play before
A foolish Lord, come let us go make us ready,
Go get a dishclout to make clean your shoes,
And I will speak for the properties, My Lord, we must
have a shoulder of mutton for a property,
And a little vinegar to make our Devil roar.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Very well: sirra see that they want nothing.

body.stage: Enter two with a table and a banquet on it, and two other, with Slie asleepe in a chaire, richlie apparelled, & the musick plaieng.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: so: sirra now go call my Lord,
And tell him that all things is ready as he willed it.

sp.speaker: Another.
sp.l: Set thou some wine upon the board
And then I will go fetch my Lord presently.

body.stage: Enter the Lord and his men.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: How now, what is all things ready?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Then sound the music, and I will wake him straight,
And see you do as erst I gave in charge.
My lord, My lord, he sleeps soundly: My lord.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Tapster, gis a little small ale. Heigh ho,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: here is wine my lord, the purest of the grape.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: for which Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: for your honour my Lord.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: who I, am I a Lord? Jesus what fine apparel have I got.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: More richer far your honour hath to wear,
And if it please you I will fetch them straight.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And if your honour please to ride abroad,
I will fetch you lusty steeds more swift of pace
Than winged Pegasus in all his pride,
that ran so swiftly over the Persian plains.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And if your honour please to hunt the deer,
Your hounds stands ready coupled at the door,
who in running will overtake the Row,
And make the long breathed Tiger broken winded.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: by the mass I think I am a Lord indeed,
what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Simon if it please your honour.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Simon that is as much to say Simion or Simon
Put forth thy hand and fill the pot.
give me thy hand, Sim. am I a lord indeed?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Aye my gracious Lord, and your lovely lady
Long time hath mourned for your absence here,
And now with joy behold where she doth come
to gratulate your honours safe return.

body.stage: Enter the boy in Womans attire.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Sim. Is this she?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Mass it is a pretty wench, what is her name?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: o that my lovely Lord would once vouchsafe
to look on me, and leave these frantic fits,
Or were I now but half so eloquent,
to paint in words what I will perform in deeds,
I know your honour then would pity me.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Hark you mistress, will you eat a piece of bread,
Come sit down on my knee, Sim drink to her Sim
for she and I will go to bed anon.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: May it please you, your honour's players be come
to offer your honour a play.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: A play Sim O brave, be they my players?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Is there not a fool in the play?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: When will they play Sim

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: even when it please your honour, they be ready.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My lord I will go bid them begin their play.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: do, but look that you come again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I warrant you my lord, I will not leave you thus.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Come Sim where be the players? Sim stand by
Me and we will flout the players out of their coats.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I will call them my lord. Ho where are you there?

body.stage: Enter two yoong Gentlemen, and a man and a boie.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Welcome to Athens my beloved friend,
to Platoes schools and Aristotles walks,
Welcome from Cestus famous for the love
Of good Leander and his Tragedy,
for whom the Helespont weeps brinish tears,
The greatest grief is I cannot as I would
give entertainment to my dearest friend.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Thanks noble Polidor my second self,
The faithful love which I have found in thee
Hath made me leave my father's princely court,
The Duke of Cestus thrice renowned seat,
to come to Athens thus to find thee out,
which since I have so happily attained,
My fortune now I do account as great
As erst did Caesar when he conquered most,
But tell me noble friend where shall we lodge,
for I am unacquainted in this place.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: My Lord if you vouchsafe of scholar's fare,
My house, my self, and all is yours to use,
You and your men shall stay and lodge with me.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: With all my heart, I will requite thy love.

body.stage: Enter Simon, Alphonsus and his three daughters.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: But stay; what dames are these so bright of hew
Whose eyes are brighter than the lamps of heaven,
Fairer than rocks of pearl and precious stone,
More lovely far than is the morning sun,
When first she opes her oriental gates.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Daughters be gone, and hie you to the church,
And I will hie me down unto the key,
to see what Merchandise is come a shore.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why how now my Lord, what in a dump,
to see these damsels pass away so soon?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Trust me my friend I must confess to thee,
I took so much delight in these fair dames,
As I do wish they had not gone so soon,
But if thou canst, resolve me what they be,
And what old man it was that went with them,
for I do long to see them once again.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I cannot blame your honour good my lord,
for they are both lovely, wise, fair and young,
And one of them the youngest of the three
I long have loved (sweet friend) and she loved me,
But never yet we could not find a means
How we might compass our desired joys.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Why, is not her father willing to the match?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes trust me, but he hath solemnly sworn,
His eldest daughter first shall be espoused,
Before he grants his youngest leave to love,
And therefore he that means to get their loves,
Must first provide for her if he will speed,
And he that hath her shall be fettered so,
As good be wedded to the devil himself,
for such a scold as she did never live,
And till that she be sped none else can speed,
which makes me think that all my labours lost,
And whosoever can get her firm good will,
A large dowry he shall be sure to have,
for her father is a man of mighty wealth,
And an ancient Citizen of the town,
And that was he that went along with them.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: But he shall keep her still by my advice,
And yet I needs must love his second daughter
The image of honour and Nobility,
in whose sweet person is comprised the sum
Of natures skill and heavenly majesty.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I like your choice, and glad you chose not mine,
Then if you like to follow on your love,
we must devise a means and find some one
that will attempt to wed this devilish scold,
And I do know the man. Come hither boy,
Go your ways sirra to Ferandoes house,
Desire him take the pains to come to me,
for I must speak with him immediately.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will sir, and fetch him presently.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A man I think will fit her humour right,
As blunt in speech as she is sharpe of tongue,
And he I think will match her every way,
And yet he is a man of wealth sufficient,
And for his person worth as good as she,
And if he compass her to be his wife,
Then may we freely visit both our loves .

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: O might I see the centre of my soul
Whose sacred beauty hath enchanted me,
More fair than was the Grecian Helena
for whose sweet sake so many princes died,
that came with thousand ships to Tenedos
But when we come unto her father's house,
Tell him I am a Merchant's son of Cestus
that comes for traffic unto Athens here,
And here sirra I will change with you for once,
And now be thou the Duke of Cestus son,
Revel and spend as if thou wert myself,
for I will court my love in this disguise.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord, how if the Duke your father should
by some means come to Athens for to see
How you do profit in these public schools,
And find me clothed thus in your attire,
How would he take it then think you my lord?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Tush fear not Valeria let me alone,
But stay, here comes some other company.

body.stage: Enter Ferando and his man Saunders with a blew coat.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here comes the man that I did tell you of.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Good morrow gentlemen to all at once.
How now Polidor what man still in love?
ever wooing and canst thou never speed,
God send me better luck when I shall woo.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I warrant you master and you take my council.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why sirra, are you so cunning?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: who I, it were better for you by five mark
And you could tell how to do it as well as I.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I would thy master once were in the vain,
to try himself how he could woe a wench.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Faith I am even now a-going .

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye faith sir, my masters going to this gear now.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whither in faith Ferando tell me true.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: to bonny Kate the patientest wench alive
The devil himself dares scarce venture to woo her,
Signior Alfonsos eldest daughter,
And he hath promised me six thousand crowns
If I can win her once to be my wife,
And she and I must woo with scolding sure,
And I will hold her to it till she be weary,
Or else I will make her yield to grant me love.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How like you this Aurelius I think he knew
our minds before we sent to him,
But tell me, when do you mean to speak with her?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Faith presently, do you but stand aside,
And I will make her father bring her hither,
And she, and I, and he, will talk alone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With all our hearts, Come Aurelius
Let us be gone and leave him here alone.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Ho Seignior Alfonso whose within there?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Seignior Ferando your welcome heartily,
You are a stranger sir unto my house.
Hark you sir, look what I did promise you
I will perform, if you get my daughters love.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Then when I have talked a word or two with her,
do you step in and give her hand to me,
And tell her when the marriage day shall be,
for I do know she would be married fain,
And when our nuptial rites be once performed
Let me alone to tame her well enough,
Now call her forth that I may speak with her.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: ha Kate Come hither wench and list to me,
Use this gentleman friendly as thou canst.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Twenty good morrows to my lovely Kate

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: You jest I am sure, is she yours already?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: I tell thee Kate I know thou lovest me well.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: The devil you do, who told you so?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: My mind sweet Kate doth say I am the man,
Must wed, and bed, and marry bonnie Kate

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Was ever seen so gross an ass as this?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Aye , to stand so long and never get a kiss.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Hands off I say, and get you from this place;
Or I will set my ten commandments in your face.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: I prithee do kate; they say thou art a shrew,
And I like thee the better for I would have thee so.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Let go my hand, for fear it reach your ear.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: no kate, this hand is mine and I thy love.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: in faith sir no the woodcock wants his tail.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: But yet his bill will serve, if the other fail.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: How now Ferando what says my daughter?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: she is willing sir and loves me as her life.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: it is for your skin then, but not to be your wife.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Come hither Kate and let me give thy hand
to him that I have chosen for thy love,
And thou tomorrow shalt be wed to him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why father, what do you mean to do with me,
to give me thus unto this brainsick man,
that in his mood cares not to murder me?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: But yet I will consent and marry him,
for I methinks have lived too long a maid,
And match him too , or else his manhoods good.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: give me thy hand Ferando loves thee well,
And will with wealth and ease maintain thy state.
Here Ferando take her for thy wife,
And sunday next shall be your wedding day.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why so, did I not tell thee I should be the man
Father, I leave my lovely Kate with you,
Provide yourselves against our marriage day,
for I must hie me to my country house
in haste, to see provision may be made,
to entertain my Kate when she doth come.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: do so, come Kate why dost thou look
so sad, be merry wench thy wedding day is at hand.
son fare you well, and see you keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: so, all thus far goes well. Ho Saunder

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Sander I faith you are a beast, I cry God heartily
Mercy, my heart is ready to run out of my belly with
Laughing, I stood behind the door all this while,
And heard what you said to her.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why didst thou think that I did not speak well to her?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: You spoke like an ass to her, I will tell you what,
If I had been there to have wooed her, and had this
Cloak on that you have, I should have had her before she
Had gone a foot further, and you talk of Woodcocks
with her, and I cannot tell you what.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: well sirra, and yet thou seest I have got her for all this.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye marry it was more by hap than any good cunning
I hope she will make you one of the head men of the parish shortly.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: well sirra leave your jesting and go to Polidors house,
The young gentleman that was here with me,
And tell him the circumstance of all thou knowest,
Tell him on sunday next we must be married,
And if he ask thee whither I am gone,
Tell him into the country to my house,
And upon sunday I will be here again.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I warrant you Master fear not me
for doing of my business.
Now hang him that has not a livery coat
to slash it out and swash it out amongst the proudest
of them. Why look you now I will scarce put up
Plain Saunder now at any of their hands, for if any
Body have any thing to do with my master, straight
They come crouching upon me, I beseech you good Master.
Saunder speak a good word for me, and then am I so
Stout and takes it upon me, and stands upon my pantofles
to them out of all cry, why I have a life like a giant
Now, but that my master hath such a pestilent mind
to a woman now of late, and I have a pretty wench
to my sister, if I had thought to have preferred my
Master to her, and that would have been a good
Deal in my way but that he is sped already.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Friend, well met.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: 'swounds, friend well met. I hold my life he sees
Not my master's livery coat,
Plain friend hop of my thumb, know you who we are.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Trust me sir it is the use where I was borne,
to salute men after this manner, yet notwithstanding
If you be angry with me for calling of you friend,
I am the more sorry for it, hoping the style
Of a fool will make you amends for all.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The slave is sorry for his fault, now we cannot be
Angry, well what is the matter that you would do with us.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Marry sir, I hear you pertain to signior Ferando

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye if thou beest not blind thou mayst see, Ecce signum here.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Shall I entreat you to do me a message to your Master?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye , it may be, and you tell us from whence you come.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Marry sir I serve young Polidor your master's friend.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Do you serve him, and what is your name?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My name sirra, I tell thee sirra is called Catapie.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Cake and pie, O my teeth waters to have a piece of thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why slave wouldst thou eat me?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Eat thee, who would not eat Cake and pie?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why villain my name is Catapie,
But wilt thou tell me where thy master is.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nay thou must first tell me where thy master is,
for I have good news for him, I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why see where he comes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come sweet Aurelius my faithful friend,
Now will we go to see those lovely dames
Richer in beauty than the orient pearl,
Whiter than is the Alpine Crystal mould,
And far more lovely than the terean plant,
that blushing in the air turns to a stone.
What Sander what news with you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Marry sir my master sends you word
that you must come to his wedding tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What, shall he be married then?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Faith Aye you think he stands as long about it as you do.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whither is thy master gone now?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Marry he is gone to our house in the Country,
to make all things in a readiness against my new
Mistress comes thither, but he will come again tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: This is suddenly dispatched belike,
Well, sirra boy, take Saunder in with you
And have him to the buttery presently.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will sir: come Saunder

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Valeria as erst we did devise,
Take thou thy lute and go to Alfonsos house,
And say that Polidor sent thee thither.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Aye Valeria for he spoke to me,
to help him to some cunning Musician,
to teach his eldest daughter on the lute,
And thou I know will fit his turn so well
As thou shalt get great favour at his hands,
Begone Valeria and say I sent thee to him.

sp.speaker: Valer
sp.l: I will sir and stay your coming at Alfonsos house.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now sweet Aurelius by this devise
Shall we have leisure for to court our loves,
for whilst that she is learning on the lute,
her sisters may take time to steel abroad,
for otherwise she will keep them both within,
And make them work whilst she herself doth play,
But come let us go unto Alfonsos house,
And see how Valeria and Kate agrees,
I doubt his Music scarce will please his scholar,
But stay here comes Alfonso

sp.speaker: Alfonso.
sp.l: What Master. Polidor you are well met,
I thank you for the man you sent to me,
A good Musician I think he is,
I have set my daughter and him together,
But is this gentleman a friend of yours?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He is, I pray you sir bid him welcome,
he is a wealthy Merchant's son of Cestus

sp.speaker: Alfonso.
sp.l: Your welcome sir and if my house afford
You any thing that may content your mind,
I pray you sir make bold with me.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I thank you sir, and if what I have got,
by merchandise or travel on the seas,
Satins or lawns or azure coloured silk,
Or precious fiery pointed stones of Indie,
You shall command both them myself and all.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Thanks gentle sir, Polidor take him in,
And bid him welcome too unto my house,
for thou I think must be my second son,
Ferando, Polidor dost thou not know
Must marry Kate and tomorrow is the day.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Such news I heard, and I came now to know.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Polidor it is true, go let me alone,
for I must see against the bridegroom come,
that all things be according to his mind,
And so I will leave you for an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come then Aureleus come in with me,
And we will go sit a while and chat with them,
And after bring them forth to take the air.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Sim when will the fool come again?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: he will come again my Lord anon.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Gis some more drink here, 'swounds where is
The Tapster, here Sim eat some of these things.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: so I do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Here Sim I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: My Lord here comes the players again ,

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: O brave, here is two fine gentlewomen.

body.stage: Enter Valeria with a Lute and Kate with him.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: The senseless trees by music have been moved
And at the sound of pleasant tuned strings,
have savage beasts hung down their listening heads,
As though they had been cast into a trance.
Then it may be that she whom nought can please,
With music's sound in time may be surprised,
Come lovely mistress will you take your lute,
And play the lesson that I taught you last?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: It is no matter whether I do or no,
for trust me I take no great delight in it.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I would sweet mistress that it lay in me,
to help you to that thing that is your delight.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: in you with a pestilence, are you so kind?
Then make a night cap of your fiddles case,
to warm your head, and hide your filthy face.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If that sweet mistress were your heart's content,
You should command a greater thing than that,
Although it were ten times to my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: You are so kind it were pity you should be hanged,
And yet methinks the fool doth look asquint.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why mistress do you mock me?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: no, but I mean to move thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, will you play a little?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Aye, give me the Lute.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: that stop was false, play it again.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then mend it thou, thou filthy ass.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, do you bid me kiss your arse?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: How now jack sauce, you are a jolly mate,
You had best be still lest I cross your pate,
And make your music fly about your ears,
I will make it and your foolish coxcomb meet.

body.stage: She offers to strike him with the lute.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hold mistress, 'swounds will you break my lute?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Aye on thy head, and if thou speak to me,
There take it up and fiddle somewhere else,

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: And see you come no more into this place,
lest that I clap your fiddle on your face.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'swounds, teach her to play upon the lute?
The devil shall teach her first, I am glad she is gone,
for I was near so afraid in all my life,
But that my lute should fly about mine ears,
My master shall teach her his self for me,
for I will keep me far enough without her reach,
for he and Polydor sent me before
to be with her and teach her on the lute,
Whilst they did court the other gentlewomen,
And here methinks they come together.

body.stage: Enter Aurelius, Polidor, Emelia and Phelina

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How now Valeria where is your mistress?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: At the vengeance I think and no where else.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Why Valeria will she not learn apace?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes berlady she has learnt too much already,
And that I had felt had I not spoke her fair,
But she shall never be learnt for me again.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Well Valeria go to my chamber,
And bear him company that came today
From Cestus where our aged father dwells.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come fair Emelia my lovely love ,
Brighter than the burnished palace of the sun,
The eye sight of the glorious firmament,
in whose bright looks sparkles the radiant fire,
Wily Prometheus slyly stole from Jove
Infusing breath, life, motion, soul,
to every object stricken by thine eyes.
o fair Emelia I pine for thee,
And either must enjoy thy love, or die.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: Fie man, I know you will not die for love:
Ah Polidor thou needst not to complain,
Eternal heaven sooner be dissolved,
And all that pierceth Phebus silver eye,
Before such hap befall to Polidor

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thanks fair Emelia for these sweet words,
But what saith Phylena to her friend?

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: Why I am buying merchandise of him.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Mistress you shall not need to buy of me,
for when I crossed the bubbling Canibey,
And sailed along the Crystal Helispont,
I filled my coffers of the wealthy mines,
Where I did cause Millions of labouring Moors
to undermine the caverns of the earth,
to seek for strange and new found precious stones,
And dive into the sea to gather pearl,
As fair as Juno offered Priams son ,
And you shall take your liberal choice of all.

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: I thank you sir and would Phylena might
in any courtesy requite you so,
As she with willing heart could well bestow.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: How now daughters, is Ferando come?

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: Not yet father, I wonder he stays so long.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: And where is your sister that she is not here?

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: She is making of her ready father
to go to church and if that he were come.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I warrant you he will not be long away.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Go daughters get you in, and bid your
Sister provide herself against that we do come,
And see you go to church along with us.
I marvel that Ferando comes not away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: His Tailor it may be hath been too slack,
in his apparel which he means to wear,
for no question but some fantastic suits
He is determined to wear today,
And richly powdered with precious stones,
Spotted with liquid gold, thick set with pearl,
And such he means shall be his wedding suits.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I cared not I what cost he did bestow,
in gold or silk, so he himself were here,
for I had rather lose a thousand crowns,
Than that he should deceive us here today,
But soft I think I see him come.

body.stage: Enter Ferando baselie attired, and a red cap on his head.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Good morrow father, Polidor well met,
You wonder I know that I have staid so long.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Aye marry son, we were almost persuaded,
that we should scarce have had our bridegroom here,
But say, why art thou thus basely attired?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Thus richly father you should have said,
for when my wife and I am married once,
she is such a shrew, if we should once fall out,
she will pull my costly suits over mine ears,
And therefore am I thus attired awhile,
for many things I tell you is in my head,
And none must know thereof but Kate and I
for we shall live like lambs and Lions sure,
Nor lambs to Lions never was so tame,
If once they lie within the Lion's paws
As Kate to me if we were married once,
And therefore come let us to church presently.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fie Ferando not thus attired for shame,
Come to my Chamber and there suit thyself,
Of twenty suits that I did never wear.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Tush Polidor I have as many suits
Fantastic made to fit my humour so
As any in Athens and as richly wrought
As was the Massy Robe that late adorned,
The stately legate of the Persian King,
And this from them have I made choice to wear.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I prithee Ferando let me entreat
Before thou goest unto the church with us,
to put some other suit upon thy back.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Not for the world if I might gain it so,
And therefore take me thus or not at all,

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: But soft se where my Kate doth come,
I must salute her: how fares my lovely Kate
What art thou ready? shall we go to church.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Not I with one so mad, so basely tired,
to marry such a filthy slavish groom,
that as it seems sometimes is from his wits,
Or else he would not thus have come to us.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Tush Kate these words adds greater love in me
And makes me think thee fairer than before,
Sweet Kate the lovelier than Dianas purple robe,
Whiter than are the snowy Apenis,
Or icy hair that grows on Boreas chin.
Father I swear by Ibis golden beak,
More fair and Radiant is my bonny Kate
Then silver Zanthus when he doth embrace,
The ruddy Simies at Idas feet,
And care not thou sweet Kate how I be clad,
Thou shalt have garments wrought of Median silk,
Enchased with precious Jewels fetched from far,
by Italian Merchants that with Russian stems,
Ploughs up huge sorrows in the Terren Maine
And better far my lovely Kate shall wear,
Than come sweet love and let us to the church,
for this I swear shall be my wedding suit.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Come gentlemen go along with us,
for thus do what we can he will be wed.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come hither sirra boy.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Boy; o disgrace to my person, 'swounds boy
Of your face, you have many boys with such
Pickdevants I am sure, 'swounds would you
Not have a bloody nose for this?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come, come, I did but jest, where is that
Same piece of pie that I gave thee to keep.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The pie? Aye you have more mind of your belly
Then to go see what your master does.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Tush it is no matter man I prithee give it me,
I am very hungry I promise thee.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why you may take it and the devil burst
You with it, one cannot save a bit after supper,
But you are always ready to munch it up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why come man, we shall have good cheer
Anon at the bride-house, for your master is gone to
Church to be married already, and there is
Such cheer as passeth.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: O brave, I would I had eat no meat this week,
for I have never a corner left in my belly
to put a venison pasty in, I think I shall burst myself
With eating, for I will so cram me down the tarts
And the march-pains, out of all cry.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Aye , but how wilt thou do now thy master is
Married, thy mistress is such a devil, as she will make
Thee forget thy eating quickly, she will beat thee so.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Let my master alone with her for that, for
he will make her tame well enough ere long I warrant thee
for he is such a churl waxen now of late that and he be
never so little angry he thumbs me out of all cry,
But in my mind sirrah the youngest is a very
Pretty wench, and if I thought thy master would
Not have her I would have a fling at her
Myself, I will see soon whether it will be a match
Or no: if it will not I will set the matter
Hard for myself I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'swounds you slave will you be a Rival with
My master in his love, speak but such
Another word and I will cut off one of thy legs.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: o, cruel judgment, nay then sirrah,
My tongue shall talk no more to you, marry my
Timber shall tell the trusty message of his master,
even on the very forehead on thee, thou abusious
Villain, therefore prepare thyself.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come hither thou Imperfectious slave in
Regard of thy beggary, hold thee there is
Two shillings for thee? to pay for the
Healing of thy left leg which I mean
Furiously to invade or to maim at the least.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: O supernodical foul? well I will take your
two shillings but I will bar striking at legs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Not I, for I will strike any where.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Here here take your two shillings again
I will see thee hanged ere I will fight with thee,
I got a broken shin the other day,
it is not, whole yet and therefore I will not fight
Come come why should we fall out?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Well sirrah your fair words hath something
Allayed my Choler: I am content for this once
to put it up and be friends with thee,
But soft see where they come all from church,
Belike they be Married already.

body.stage: Enter Ferando and Kate and Alfonso and Polidor and Emelia and Aurelius and Philema

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Father farewell, my Kate and I must home,
Sirrah go make ready my horse presently.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Your horse what son I hope you do but jest,
I am sure you will not go so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Let him go or tarry I am resolved to stay,
And not to travel on my wedding day.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Tut Kate I tell thee we must needs go home,
Villain hast thou saddled my horse?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: which horse, your curtal?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: 'swounds you slave stand you prating here?
Saddle the bay gelding for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Not for me: for I will not go.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The ostler will not let me have him, you owe ten pence.
for his meat, and 6 pence for stuffing my mistress saddle.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Here villain go pay him straight.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Shall I give them another peck of lavender.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Out slave and bring them presently to the door

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Why son I hope at least you will dine with us.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I pray you master let us stay till dinner be done.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: 'swounds villain art thou here yet?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come Kate our dinner is provided at home.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: But not for me, for here I mean to dine.
I will have my will in this as well as you,
Though you in madding mood would leave your friends
Despite of you I will tarry with them still.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Aye Kate so thou shalt but at some other time,
When as thy sisters here shall be espoused,
Then thou and I will keep our wedding day,
in better sort than now we can provide,
for here I promise thee before them all,
we will ere long return to them again ,
Come Kate stand not on terms we will away ,
This is my day, tomorrow thou shalt rule,
And I will do what ever thou commands.
Gentlemen farewell, we will take our leaves,
It will be late before that we come home.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Farewell Ferando since you will be gone.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: so mad a couple did I never see.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.l: They are even as well matched as I would wish.

sp.speaker: Phile.
sp.l: And yet I hardly think that he can tame her.
for when he has done she will do what she list.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: her manhood then is good I do believe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Aurelius or else I miss my mark,
her tongue will walk if she doth hold her hands,
I am in doubt ere half a month be past
He will curse the priest that married him so soon ,
And yet it may be she will be reclaimed,
for she is very patient grown of late.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: God hold it that it may continue still,
I would be loath that they should disagree,
But he I hope will hold her in a while.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Within this two days I will ride to him,
And see how lovingly they do agree.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Now Aurelius what say you to this,
What have you sent to Cestus as you said,
to certify your father of your love,
for I would gladly he would like of it,
And if he be the man you tell to me,
I guess he is a Merchant of great wealth.
And I have seen him oft at Athens here,
And for his sake assure thee thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And so to me whilst Polidor doth live.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I find it so right worthy gentlemen,
And of what worth your friendship I esteem,
I leave censure of your several thoughts,
But for requital of your favours past,
Rests yet behind, which when occasion serves
I vow shall be remembered to the full,
And for my father's coming to this place,
I do expect within this week at most.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: enough Aurelieus but we forget
our Marriage dinner now the bride is gone,
Come let us se what there they left behind.

body.stage: Enter Sanders with two or three seruing men

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Come sirs provide all things as fast as you can,
for my Masters hard at hand and my new Mistress
And all, and he sent me before to see all things ready.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Welcome home Sander sirrah how looks our
New Mistress they say she is a plaguey shrew.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye and that thou shalt find I can tell thee if thou
Dost not please her well, why my Master
Has such a do with her as it passeth and he is even
like a madman.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Why Sander what does he say.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why I will tell you what: when they should
Go to church to be married he puts on an old
Jerkin and a pair of canvas breeches down to the
Small of his leg and a red cap on his head and he
looks as thou wilt burst thyself with laughing
When thou seest him: he is even as good as a
Fool for me: and then when they should go to dinner
He made me Saddle the horse and away he came.
And never tarried for dinner and therefore you had best
Get supper reddy against they come, for
They be hard at hand I am sure by this time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: 'swounds see where they be all ready.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Now welcome Kate where is these villains
Here, what? not supper yet upon the board:
Nor table spread nor nothing done at all,
where is that villain that I sent before.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Now, adsum sir.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come hither you villain I will cut your nose,
You Rogue: help me off with my boots: wilt please
You to lay the cloth? 'swounds the villain
Hurts my foot? pull easily I say; yet again.

body.stage: They couer the bord and fetch in the meate.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: 'swounds? burnt and scorched who dressed this meat?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Forsooth Iohn cook.

body.stage: He throwes downe the table and meate and all, and beates them.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Go you villains bring you me such meat,
Out of my sight I say and bear it hence,
Come Kate we will have other meat provided,
Is there a fire in my chamber sir?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye forsooth.

body.stage: Manent seruingmen and eate vp all the meate.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: 'swounds? I think of my conscience my Masters
Mad since he was married.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I laughed what a box he gave Sander
for pulling off his boots.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I hurt his foot for the nonce man.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Did you so you damned villain.

body.stage: He beates them all out againe.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: This humour must I hold me to a while,
to bridle and hold back my headstrong wife,
With curbs of hunger: ease: and want of sleep,
Nor sleep nor meat shall she enjoy tonight ,
I will mew her up as men do mew their hawks,
And make her gently come unto the lure,
Were she as stubborn or as full of strength
As were the Thracian horse Alcides tamed,
that King Egeus fed with flesh of men,
Yet would I pull her down and make her come
As hungry hawks do fly unto their lure.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Valeria attend: I have a lovely love ,
As bright as is the heaven crystalline,
As fair as is the milk white way of Jove,
As chaste as Phoebe in her summer sports,
As soft and tender as the assure down,
that circles Cithereas silver doves.
her do I mean to make my lovely bride,
And in her bed to breath the sweet content,
that I thou knowest long time have aimed at.
Now Valeria it rests in thee to help
to compass this, that I might gain my love ,
which easily thou mayst perform at will,
If that the merchant which thou toldest me of,
will as he said go to Alfonsos house,
And say he is my father, and there with all
Pass over certain deeds of land to me,
that I thereby may gain my hearts desire,
And he is promised reward of me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: fear not my Lord I will fetch him straight to you,
for he will do any thing that you command,
But tell me my Lord, is Ferando married then?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: He is: and Polidor shortly shall be wed,
And he means to tame his wife ere long.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: He says so.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Faith he is gone unto the taming school.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The taming school; why is there such a place?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Aye : and Ferando is the Master of the school.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: that is rare: but what decorum does he use?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Faith I know not: but by some odd device
Or other, but come Valeria I long to see the man,
by whom we must comprise our plotted drift,
that I may tell him what we have to do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then come my Lord and I will bring you to him straight.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Agreed, then let us go.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Come Mistress.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Sander I prithee help me to some meat,
I am so faint that I can scarcely stand.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye marry mistress but you know my master
Has given me a charge that you must eat nothing,
But that which he himself giveth you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why man thy Master needs never know it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: You say true indeed: why look you Mistress,
What say you to a piece of beef and mustard now?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why I say it is excellent meat, canst thou help me to some?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye , I could help you to some but that
I doubt the mustard is too choleric for you,
But what say you to a sheep's head and garlic?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why any thing, I care not what it be.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye but the garlic I doubt will make your breath stink, and then my Master will curse me for letting
You eat it: But what say you to a fat Capon?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: that is meat for a King sweet Sander help
Me to some of it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nay berlady then it is too dear for us, we must
Not meddle with the King's meat.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: Out villain dost thou mock me,
Take that for thy sauciness.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: 'swounds are you so light fingered with a murrain,
I will keep you fasting for it this two days.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I tell thee villain I will tear the flesh off
Thy face and eat it if thou prates to me thus.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Here comes my Master now he will course you.

body.stage: Enter Ferando with a peece of meate vppon his daggers point and Polidor with him.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Se here Kate I have provided meat for thee,
Here take it: what is it not worthy thanks,
go sirrah? take it away again you shall be
Thankful for the next you have.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: Why I thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Nay now it is not worth a pin go sirrah and take
It hence I say.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes sir I will Carry it hence: Master let her
have none for she can fight as hungry as she is.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I pray you sir let it stand, for I will eat
Some with her myself.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Well sirrah set it down again .

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nay nay I pray you let him take it hence,
And keep it for your own diet for I will none,
I will never be beholding to you for your Meat,
I tell thee flatly here unto thee thy teethe
Thou shalt not keep me nor feed me as thou list,
for I will home again unto my father's house.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Aye , when you are meek and gentle but not
Before, I know your stomach is not yet come down,
Therefore no marvel thou canst not eat,
And I will go unto your father's house,
Come Polidor let us go in again,
And Kate come in with us I know ere long,
that thou and I shall lovingly agree.

body.stage: Enter Aurelius Valeria and Phylotus the Marchant

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Now Senior Phylotus we will go
unto Alfonsos house, and be sure you say
As I did tell you, concerning the man
that dwells in Cestus whose son I said I was,
for you do very much resemble him,
And fear not: you may be bold to speak your mind.

sp.speaker: Phylo.
sp.l: I warrant you sir take you no care,
I will use myself so cunning in the cause,
As you shall soon enjoy your heart's delight.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Thanks sweet Phylotus then stay you here,
And I will go and fetch him hither straight.
Ho, Senior Alfonso a word with you.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Who is there? what Aurelius what is the matter
that you stand so like a stranger at the door?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: My father sir is newly come to town,
And I have brought him here to speak with you,
Concerning those matters that I told you of,
And he can certify you of the truth.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Is this your father? you are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Phylo.
sp.l: Thanks Alfonso for that is your name I guess,
I understand my son hath set his mind
And bent his liking to your daughters love,
And for because he is my only son,
And I would gladly that he should do well,
I tell you sir, I not mislike his choice,
If you agree to give him your consent,
He shall have living to maintain his state,
Three hundred pounds a year I will assure
to him and to his heirs, and if they do join,
And knit themselves in holy wedlock band,
A thousand massy ingots of pure gold,
And twice as many bares of silver plate,
I freely give him, and in writing straight,
I will confirm what I have said in words.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Trust me I must commend your liberal mind,
And loving care you bear unto your son,
And here I give him freely my consent,
As for my daughter I think he knows her mind,
And I will enlarge her dowry for your sake.
And solemnise with joy your nuptial rites,
But is this gentleman of Cestus too?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: He is the Duke of Cestus thrice renowned son,
who for the love his honour bears to me:
Hath thus accompanied me to this place.

sp.speaker: Alfonso.
sp.l: You were to blame you told me not before,
Pardon me my Lord, for if I had known
Your honour had been here in place with me,
I would have done my duty to your honour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thanks good Alfonso but I did come to see
When as these marriage rites should be performed,
And if in these nuptials you vouchsafe,
to honour thus the prince of Cestus friend,
in celebration of his spousal rites,
He shall remain a lasting friend to you,
What says Aurelius father.

sp.speaker: Phylo.
sp.l: I humbly thank your honour good my Lord,
And ere we part before your honour here:
Shall articles of such content be drawn,
As twixt our houses and posterities,
Eternally this league of peace shall last,
Inviolate and pure on either part:

sp.speaker: Alfonso.
sp.l: With all my heart, and if your honour please,
to walk along with us unto my house,
we will confirm these leagues of lasting love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come then Aurelius I will go with you.

body.stage: Enter Ferando and Kate and Sander

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Master the haberdasher has brought my
Mistress home her cap here.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come hither sirrah: what have you there?

sp.speaker: Habar.
sp.l: A velvet cap sir if it please you.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: who spoke for it? didst thou Kate

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: What if I did, come hither sirrah, give me
The cap, I will see if it will fit me.

body.stage: She sets it one hir head.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: O monstrous: why it becomes thee not,
Let me see it Kate here sirrah take it hence,
This cap is out of fashion quite.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: The fashion is good enough: belike you,
Mean to make a fool of me.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why true he means to make a fool of thee,
to have thee put on such a curtailed cap,
sirrah begone with it.

body.stage: Enter the Taylor with a gowne.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Here is the Taylor too with my Mistress gown.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Let me see it Taylor what with cuts and jags?
'swounds you villain, thou hast spoiled the gown.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: Why sir I made it as your man gave me direction,
You may read the note here.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come hither sirrah: Taylor read the note.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: Item a fair round compassed cape.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Aye that is true.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: And a large trunk sleeve.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: that is a lie master, I said two trunk sleeves.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Well sir go forward.

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.l: Item a loose bodied gown.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Master if ever I said loose bodies gown,
Sew me in a seam and beat me to death,
With a bottom of brown thread.

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.l: I made it as the note bad me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I say the note lies in his throat and thou too,
And thou sayst it.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: Nay nay never be so hot sirrah, for I fear you not.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: dost thou hear Taylor thou hast braved
Many men: brave not me.
Thou hast fast many men.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Face not me I will neither be fast nor braved
At thy hands I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Come come I like the fashion of it well enough,
here is more ado than needs I will have it,
And if you do not like it hide your eyes,
I think I shall have nothing by your will.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Go I say and take it up for your master's use.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: 'swounds: villain not for thy life touch it not,
'swounds, take up my mistress gown to his
Master's use?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Well sir: what is your conceit of it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I have a deeper conceit in it than you
think for, take up my Mistress gown
to his master's use?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Tailor come hither: for this time take it
Hence again, and I will content thee for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come Kate we now will go see thy father's house
even in these honest mean habiliments,
our purses shall be rich, our garments plain,
to shroud our bodies from the winter rage,
And that is enough, what should we care for more.
Thy sisters Kate tomorrow must be wed,
And I have promised them thou shouldst be there
The morning is well up let us haste away,
It will be nine o'clock ere we come there.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nine o'clock, why it is already past two
in the afternoon by all the clocks in the town.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: I say it is but nine o'clock in the morning.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I say it is two o'clock in the after noon.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: It shall be nine then ere we go to your father's,
Come back again, we will not go today .
Nothing but crossing of me still,
I will have you say as I do ere you go.

body.stage: Enter Polidor, Emelia, Aurelius and Philema

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: fair Emelia summer's sun bright Queen,
Brighter of hew than is the burning clime,
Where Phoebus in his bright equator sits,
Creating gold and precious minerals,
What would Emelia do? if I were forced
to leave fair Athens and to range the world.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: Should thou assay to scale the seat of love,
Mounting the subtle airy regions
Or be snatched up as erst was Ganimed
love should give wings unto my swift desires,
And prune my thoughts that I would follow thee,
Or fall and perish as did Icarus

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Sweetly resolved fair Emelia
But would Phylema say as much to me,
If I should ask a question now of thee,
What if the duke of Cestus only son,
which came with me unto your father's house,
Should seek to get Phylemas love from me,
And make thee Duchess of that stately town,
Wouldst thou not then forsake me for his love?

sp.speaker: Phyle:
sp.l: Not for great Neptune no nor Jove himself,
will Phylema leave Aurelius love,
Could he install me Empress of the world,
Or make me Queen and guideress of the heavens,
Yet would I not exchange thy love for his,
Thy company is poor Philemas heaven,
And without thee, heaven were hell to me.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: And should my love as erst did Hercules
Attempt to pass the burning vaults of hell,
I would with piteous looks and pleasing words,
As once did Orpheus with his harmony,
And ravishing sound of his melodious harp,
Entreat grim Pluto and of him obtain,
that thou mightst go and safe return again .

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: And should my love as erst Leander did,
Attempt to swim the boiling helispont
for Heros love: no towers of brass should hold
But I would follow thee through those raging floods,
With locks dishevelled and my breast all bare,
With bended knees upon Abidas shore,
I would with smoky sighs and brinish tears,
Importune Neptune and the watery Gods,
to send a guard of silver scaled Dolphins
With sounding Tritons to be our convoy,
And to transport us safe unto the shore,
Whilst I would hang about thy lovely neck,
Redoubling kiss on kiss upon thy cheeks,
And with our pastime still the swelling waves.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: Should Polidor as great Achilles did,
only employ himself to follow arms,
like to the warlike Amazonian Queen,
Pentheselea Hectors paramour,
who foiled the bloody Pirrhus murderous greek,
I will thrust myself amongst the thickest throngs,
And with my utmost force assist my love.

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: Let Eole storm: be mild and quiet thou,
Let Neptune swell, be Aurelius calm and pleased,
I care not I, betide what may betide,
Let fates and fortune do the worst they can,
I reck them not: they not discord with me,
Whilst that my love and I do well agree.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Sweet Phylema beauty's mineral,
From whence the sun exhales his glorious shine,
And clad the heaven in thy reflected rays,
And now my liefest love, the time draws nigh,
that Himen mounted in his saffron robe,
Must with his torches wait upon thy train,
As Hellens brothers on the horned Moon,
Now Juno to thy number shall I add,
The fairest bride that ever Merchant had.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come fair Emelia the priest is gone ,
And at the church your father and the rest,
Do stay to see our marriage rites performed,
And knit in sight of heaven this Gordian knot.
that teeth of fretting time may never untwist,
Then come fair love and gratulate with me,
This day's content and sweet solemnity.

sp.speaker: Slie
sp.l: Sim must they be married now.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

body.stage: Enter Ferando and Kate and Sander

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: look Sim the fool is come again now.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Sirrah go fetch our horses forth, and bring
Them to the back gate presently.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I will sir I warrant you,

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come Kate the Moon shines clear tonight methinks.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: The moon? why husband you are deceived
It is the sun.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Yet again: come back again it shall be
The moon ere we come at your father's.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why I will say as you say it is the moon.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Jesus save the glorious moon.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Jesus save the glorious moon.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: I am glad Kate your stomach is come down,
I know it well thou knowest it is the sun,
But I did try to see if thou wouldst speak,
And cross me now as thou hast done before,
And trust me kate hadst thou not named the moon,
we had gone back again as sure as death,
But soft who is this that is coming here.

body.stage: Enter the Duke of Cestus alone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thus all alone from Cestus am I come,
And left my princely court and noble train,
to come to Athens and in this disguise,
to see what course my son Aurelius takes,
But stay, here is some it may be Travels thither,
Good sir can you direct me the way to Athens

body.stage: Ferando speakes to the olde man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: fair lovely maid young and affable,
More clear of hew and far more beautiful,
Than precious Sardonix or purple rocks,
Of Amithests or glistering Hiasinthe
More amiable far than is the plain,
Where glistering Cepherus in silver bowers,
Gazeth upon the Giant Andromede
Sweet Kate entertain this lovely woman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I think the man is mad he calls me a woman.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: fair lovely lady, bright and Crystalline,
Beauteous and stately as the eye trained bird,
As glorious as the morning washed with dew,
Within whose eyes she takes her dawning beams,
And golden summer sleeps upon thy cheeks,
Wrap up thy radiations in some cloud,
lest that thy beauty make this stately town,
Inhabitable like the burning Zone
With sweet reflections of thy lovely face.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What is she mad too ? or is my shape transformed,
that both of them persuade me I am a woman,
But they are mad sure, and therefore I will begone,
And leave their companies for fear of harm,
And unto Athens haste to seek my son.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why so Kate this was friendly done of thee,
And kindly too: why thus must we two live,
One mind, one heart, and one content for both,
This good old man does think that we are mad,
And glad he is I am sure, that he is gone,
But come sweet Kate for we will after him,
And now persuade him to his shape again.

body.stage: Enter Alfonso and Phylotus and Valeria, Polidor, Emelia, Aurelius and Phylema

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Come lovely sons your marriage rites performed,
let us hie us home to see what cheer we have,
I wonder that Ferando and his wife
Comes not to see this great solemnity.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: no marvel if Ferando be away,
His wife I think hath troubled so his wits,
that he remains at home to keep them warm,
for forward wedlock as the proverb says,
Hath brought him to his nightcap long ago.

sp.speaker: Phylo.
sp.l: But Polidor let my son and you take heed,
that Ferando say not ere long as much to you,
And now Alfonso more to show my love,
If unto Cestus you do send your ships,
Myself will fraught them with Arabian silks,
Rich affrick spices Arras counterpoints,
Musk Cassia sweet smelling Ambergris
Pearl, coral, crystal, jet, and ivory,
to gratulate the favours of my son,
And friendly love that you have shone to him.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: And for to honour him and this fair bride,

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I will yearly send you from my father's court,
Chests of refined sugar severally,
Ten tun of tunis wine, sucket sweet drugs,
to celebrate and solemnise this day,
And custom free your merchants shall converse:
And interchange the profits of your land,
Sending you gold for brass, silver for lead,
Cases of silk for packs of wool and cloth,
to bind this friendship and confirm this league.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am glad sir that you would be so frank,
Are you become the Duke of Cestus son,
And revels with my treasure in the town,
Base villain that thus dishonourest me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'swounds it is the Duke what shall I do,
Dishonour thee why, knowest thou what thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: here is no villain: he will not know me now,
But what say you? have you forgot me too?

sp.speaker: Phylo.
sp.l: Why sir, are you acquainted with my son?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: With thy son? no trust me if he be thine,
I pray you sir who am I?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Pardon me father: humbly on my knees,
I do entreat your grace to hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Peace villain: lay hands on them,
And send them to prison straight.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: I say we will have no sending to prison.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: My Lord this is but the play, they are but in jest.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: I tell thee Sim we will have no sending,
to prison that is flat: why Sim am not I don Christo Vary
Therefore I say they shall not go to prison.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: no more they shall not my Lord,
They be run away.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Are they run away Sim that is well,
Then gis some more drink, and let them play again .

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

body.stage: Slie drinkes and then falls a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ah treacherous boy that durst presume,
to wed thyself without thy father's leave,
I swear by fair Cintheas burning rays,
by Merops head and by seven mouthed Nile
Had I but known ere thou hadst wedded her,
Were in thy breast the worlds immortal soul,
This angry sword should rip thy hateful chest,
And hewed thee smaller than the Libian sands,
Turn hence thy face: o cruel impious boy,
Alfonso I did not think you would presume,
to match your daughter with my princely house,
And never make me acquainted with the cause.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: My Lord by heavens I swear unto your grace,
I knew none other but Valeria your man,
Had been the Duke of Cestus noble son,
Nor did my daughter I dare swear for her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: that damned villain that hath deluded me,
whom I did send guide unto my son,
o that my furious force could cleave the earth,
that I might muster bands of hellish fiends,
to rack his heart and tear his impious soul.
The ceaseless turning of celestial orbs,
Kindles not greater flames in flitting air,
Than passionate anguish of my raging breast,

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Then let my death sweet father end your grief,
for I it is that thus have wrought your woes,
Then be revenged on me for here I swear,
that they are innocent of what I did,
o had I charge to cut off Hydraes head,
to make the topless Alps a champion field,
to kill untamed monsters with my sword,
to travel daily in the hottest sun,
And watch in winter when the nights be cold,
I would with gladness undertake them all,
And think the pain but pleasure that I felt,
so that my noble father at my return,
Would but forget and pardon my offence,

sp.speaker: Phile.
sp.l: Let me entreat your grace upon my knees,
to pardon him and let my death discharge
The heavy wrath your grace hath vowed against him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And good my Lord let us entreat your grace,
to purge your stomach of this Melancholy,
Taint not your princely mind with grief my Lord,
But pardon and forgive these lovers' faults,
that kneeling crave your gracious favour here.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.l: Great prince of Cestus let a woman's words,
Entreat a pardon in your lordly breast,
Both for your princely son, and us my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Aurelius stand up I pardon thee,
I see that vertue will have enemies,
And fortune will be thwarting honour still,
And you fair virgin too I am content,
to accept you for my daughter since it is done,
And see you princely used in Cestus court.

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: Thanks good my Lord and I no longer live,
Then I obey and honour you in all:

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Let me give thanks unto your royal grace,
for this great honour done to me and mine,
And if your grace will walk unto my house,
I will in humblest manner I can, show
The eternal service I do owe your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thanks good Alfonso but I came alone,
And not as did beseem the Cestian Duke
Nor would I have it known within the town,
that I was here and thus without my train,
But as I came alone so will I go,
And leave my son to solemnise his feast,
And ere it belong I will come again to you,
And do him honour as beseems the son
Of mighty Ierobell the Cestian Duke
Till when I will leave you, Farewell Aurelius

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Not yet my Lord, I will bring you to your ship.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Who is within there? come hither sirs my Lords
A sleep again: go take him easily up,
And put him in his own apparel again,
And lay him in the place where we did find him,
Just underneath the alehouse side below,
But see you wake him not in any case.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: It shall be done my Lord come help to bear him hence,

body.stage: Enter Ferando, Aurelius and Polidor and his boy and Valeria and Sander

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Come gentlemen now that suppers done,
How shall we spend the time till we go to bed?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Faith if you will in trial of our wives,
who will come soonest at their husbands call.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay then Ferando he must needs sit out,
for he may call I think till he be weary,
Before his wife will come before she list.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: it is well for you that have such gentle wives,
Yet in this trial will I not sit out,
It may be Kate will come as soon as yours.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: My wife comes soonest for a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I take it: I will lay as much to yours,
that my wife comes as soon as I do send.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How now Ferando you dare not lay belike.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why true I dare not lay indeed;
But how, so little money on so sure a thing,
A hundred pound: why I have laid as much
upon my dog, in running at a deer,
She shall not come so far for such a trifle,
But will you lay five hundred marks with me,
And whose wife soonest comes when he doth call,
And shows herself most loving unto him,
Let him enjoy the wager I have laid,
Now what say you? dare you adventure thus?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I were it a thousand and pounds I durst presume
on my wife's love: and I will lay with thee.
Enter Alfonso

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: How now sons what in conference so hard,
May I without offence, know where abouts.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Faith father a weighty cause about our wives
Five hundred marks already we have laid,
And he whose wife doth show most love to him,
He must enjoy the wager to himself.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Why then Ferando he is sure to lose,
I promise thee son thy wife will hardly come,
And therefore I would not wish thee lay so much.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Tush father were it ten times more,
I durst adventure on my lovely Kate
But if I lose I will pay, and so shall you.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: upon mine honour if I loose I will pay.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And so will I upon my faith I vow.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Then sit we down and let us send for them.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I promise thee Ferando I am afraid thou wilt lose

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I will send for my wife first, Valeria
Go bid your Mistress come to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Now for my hundred pound.
Would any lay ten hundred more with me,
I know I should obtain it by her love.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: I pray God you have not laid too much already.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Trust me Ferando I am sure you have,
for you I dare presume have lost it all.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Now sirrah what says your mistress?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She is something busy but she will come anon.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Why so, did not I tell you this before,
She is busy and cannot come.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I pray God your wife send you so good an answer
She may be busy yet she says she will come.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Well well: Polidor send you for your wife.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Agreed Boy desire your mistress to come hither.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will sir

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Aye so so he desires her to come.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Polidor I dare presume for thee,
I think thy wife will not deny to come.
And I do marvel much Aurelius
that your wife came not when you sent for her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now where is your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She bad me tell you that she will not come,
If you have any business, you must come to her.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: o monstrous intolerable presumption,
Worse than a blazing star, or snow at midsummer,
Earthquakes or any thing unseasonable,
She will not come: but he must come to her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well sir I pray you let us hear what
Answer your wife will make.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Sirrah, command your Mistress to come
to me presently.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I think my wife for all she did not come,
will prove most kind for now I have no fear,
for I am sure Ferandos wife, she will not come.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: The more is the pity: then I must lose.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: But I have won for see where Kate doth come.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Sweet husband did you send for me?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: I did my love I sent for thee to come,
Come hither Kate what is that upon thy head

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nothing husband but my cap I think.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Pull it off and tread it under thy feet,
it is foolish I will not have thee wear it.

body.stage: She takes of her cap and treads on it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: o wonderful metamorphosis.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: This is a wonder: almost past belief.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: This is a token of her true love to me,
And yet I will try her further you shall see,
Come hither Kate where are thy sisters.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: They be sitting in the bridal chamber.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Fetch them hither and if they will not come,
Bring them perforce and make them come with thee.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I promise thee Ferando I would have sworn,
Thy wife would never have done so much for thee.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: But you shall see she will do more than this,
for see where she brings her sisters forth by force.

body.stage: Enter Kate thrusting Phylema and Emelia before her, and makes them come vnto their husbands call.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: See husband I have brought them both.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: it is well done Kate

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: Aye sure and like a loving piece, your worthy
to have great praise for this attempt.

sp.speaker: Phyle.
sp.l: Aye for making a fool of herself and us.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Beshrew thee Phylema thou hast
Lost me a hundred pound tonight .
for I did lay that thou wouldst first have come.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But thou Emelia hast lost me a great deal more.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: You might have kept it better then,
who bad you lay?

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Now lovely Kate before their husbands here,
I prithee tell unto these headstrong women,
What duty wives do owe unto their husbands.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then you that live thus by your pampered wills,
Now list to me and mark what I shall say,
The eternal power that with his only breath,
Shall cause this end and this beginning frame,
Not in time, nor before time, but with time, confused,
for all the course of years, of ages, months,
Of seasons temperate, of days and hours,
Are tuned and stopped, by measure of his hand,
The first world was, a form, without a form,
A heap confused a mixture all deformed,
A gulf of gulfs, a body bodiless,
Where all the elements were orderless,
Before the great commander of the world,
The King of Kings the glorious God of heaven;
who in six days did frame his heavenly work,
And made all things to stand in perfect course.
Then to his image he did make a man.
Old Adam and from his side a sleep,
A rib was taken, of which the Lord did make,
The woe of man so termed by Adam then,
Woman for that, by her came sin to us,
And for her sin was Adam doomed to die,
As Sara to her husband, so should we,
Obey them, love them, keep, and nourish them,
If they by any means do want our helps,
Laying our hands under their feet to tread,
If that by that we, might procure their ease,
And for a president I will first begin,
And lay my hand under my husbands feet

body.stage: She laies her hand vnder her husbands feete.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: enough sweet, the wager thou hast won,
And they I am sure cannot deny the same.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Aye Ferando the wager thou hast won,
And for to show thee how I am pleased in this,
A hundred pounds I freely give thee more,
Another dowry for another daughter,
for she is not the same she was before.

sp.speaker: Feran.
sp.l: Thanks sweet father, gentlemen goodnight
for Kate and I will leave you for tonight,
it is Kate and I am wed, and you are sped.
And so farewell for we will to our beds.

body.stage: Exit Ferando and Kate and Sander.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Now Aurelius what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Believe me father I rejoice to see,
Ferando and his wife so lovingly agree.

body.stage: Exit Aurelius and Phylema and Alfonso and Valeria.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: How now Polidor in a dump, what sayst thou man?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I say thou art a shrew.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.l: that is better than a sheep.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well since it is done let it go, come let us in.

body.stage: Then enter two bearing of Slie in his owne apparrell againe, and leaues him Where they found him, and then goes out. Then enter the Tapster

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.l: Now that the darksome night is overpassed,
And dawning day appears in crystal sky,
Now must I haste abroad: but soft who is this?
What Sly o wondrous hath he lain here all night,
I will wake him, I think he is starved by this,
But that his belly was so stuffed with ale,
What now Slie Awake for shame.

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Sim gis some more wine: what is all the
Players gone: am not I a Lord?

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.l: A Lord with a murrain: come art thou drunken still?

sp.speaker: Slie.
sp.l: Who is this? Tapster o Lord sirrah, I have had
The bravest dream tonight , that ever thou
Hardest in all thy life.

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.l: Aye marry but you had best get you home,
for your wife will course you for dreaming here tonight ,

sp.speaker: Slie
sp.l: will she? I know now how to tame a shrew,
I dreamt upon it all this night till now,
And thou hast waked me out of the best dream
that ever I had in my life, but I will to my
Wife presently and tame her too
And if she anger me.

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.l: Nay tarry Slie for I will go home with thee,
And hear the rest that thou hast dreamt tonight .
